text: As students are working on the Initial Challenge and What If, check to see if students are using a variety of strategies to represent and solve the questions. Have students think about other ways to compare the quantities. Look for interesting strategies and have students present these in the Summarize.

• For the various Situations and questions, are the ratios you are writing part-to-part or part-to-whole? (Answers will vary. Students are likely to answer that all are part to part. The Smoothie Bar scenario could be either. In the Reading Speed scenario, it does not make sense to find a whole because it is a rate. Height of Trees are two similar figures, and students will probably keep the parts of height and base. With Student Council Representation students are likely to discuss part-to-whole.)
  • What are some strategies that you have heard for finding two equivalent ratios? (Answers might include: scaling ratios, drawing pictures, using scale factors, ratio tables, unit rate, and proportions.)
  • For What If Situation A, what strategies are you using to solve for x? (Answers will vary. Students may use strategies like those mentioned above.)
  • For Situation B, what would a proportion look like for that situation? (Answers will vary.)

As you walk around the room, take note of groups that have different strategies for the same situation. This will allow you to have groups present many ways of thinking about the proportions. Also, you will be able to help connect how the strategies connect mathematically with different representations.
What evidence will you use in the Summary to clarify and deepen understanding of the Now What Do You Know? What will you do if you do not have evidence?
How are proportions like other strategies that you have used to solve ratio problems? How are they different?

(As you are circulating during the Explore listen for students using the language of equivalent ratios and then how they use that to write and solve proportions. Find different examples of how students looked at the relationships in each context to compare- equivalent ratios, ratio tables, unit rates and proportions.)
